metadata.description: Supplementary country data for AI acceptance and high-tech adoption, compiled to fill gaps in the main dataset. Countries not covered by direct surveys use estimates based on regional indices, readiness scores, and neighboring country data.
sources: Oxford Insights Government AI Readiness Index 2024 (188 countries)
IMD World Digital Competitiveness Ranking 2024 (67 countries)
Eurobarometer Special 554 - AI and the Future of Work (April-May 2024, 27 EU countries)
Lloyd's Register Foundation / Gallup World Risk Poll 2021 (121 countries, AI attitudes)
ILIA Latin American AI Index 2024 (19 countries)
Tortoise Media Global AI Index 2024 (83 countries)
Standard Insights AI & Automation Southeast Asia Survey 2024
ISEAS State of Southeast Asia Survey 2024
metadata.methodology_notes: ai_acceptance_score: For countries with direct survey data, scores are derived from survey results (e.g., % believing AI has more benefits than drawbacks, or excitement about AI). For countries without direct surveys, scores are estimated using: (1) regional survey patterns from Eurobarometer/World Risk Poll, (2) Oxford Insights readiness scores as a proxy for institutional AI engagement, (3) neighboring country data with similar development profiles. high_tech_adoption: Derived from Oxford Insights, IMD, ITU ICT, and Tortoise indices, normalized to 0-100 scale. confidence_level: 'high' = direct survey data available; 'medium' = partial data or strong proxy; 'low' = estimated from regional/development indicators.

data.notes: IMD rank 48 (55.50). Oxford Insights 2024 ~rank 76. Leads Central Asia in AI readiness. No direct public opinion survey available; score estimated from IMD digital competitiveness and regional patterns.

Perfect Vision score (100) in Oxford Insights. National AI strategy approved 2024. Rank ~62 in 2025 index (54.69). Higher acceptance estimated due to strong government promotion; lower tech adoption due to infrastructure gaps.
No direct survey data. Estimated based on Central Asian regional patterns and very limited internet penetration. Among lowest in region for digital infrastructure.
No direct survey data. Low-income country with limited digital infrastructure. Estimated from regional patterns and development indicators.
No direct survey data. Slightly higher digital engagement than Tajikistan/Turkmenistan. Estimated from Central Asian development indicators.

2024 SE Asia workplace AI survey indicates Myanmar respondents generally viewed AI as opportunity for professional growth. Political instability limits tech adoption. Score reflects positive attitude but low infrastructure.
2024 SE Asia survey showed 40.6% job security concerns about AI, but generally positive attitudes. Moderate digital growth. Asian Barometer Wave included Cambodia.
No direct survey data. Estimated from SE Asian regional patterns. Low digital infrastructure but growing mobile connectivity.

ITU ICT score 93.6, very high connectivity. No direct AI attitude survey, but high-income country with strong digital infrastructure suggests moderate-to-positive AI attitudes. Estimated from SE Asian high-income patterns.
Strong university system producing AI research. Sanctions limit tech adoption. No direct public opinion survey. Estimated based on educated population and Middle Eastern patterns.
No direct AI survey data. Arab Barometer Wave VIII included Iraq but did not focus on AI. Estimated from MENA regional patterns and development indicators.
IMD rank 57 (47.00). Strong tech sector and education system. Arab Barometer included Jordan. National AI strategy in place. Estimated from indices and regional patterns.
Economic crisis has impacted tech sector. Educated population with historically strong tech talent. Arab Barometer included Lebanon. Estimated from MENA patterns adjusted for economic conditions.
ITU ICT score 98.4 (among highest globally). High-income GCC country. Estimated from UAE/Saudi patterns and very high digital infrastructure scores.
IMD rank 28 (73.00). ITU score 98.4. Oxford Insights 2025 rank 54. Emerging as MENA AI leader. Strong government AI investment. Estimated from indices and GCC regional patterns.
IMD rank 42 (62.00). ITU score 97.5. GCC country with strong digital infrastructure. Estimated from indices and Gulf state patterns.
GCC country with national AI strategy. Moderate digital infrastructure compared to UAE/Saudi. Estimated from GCC patterns and development indicators.
Ongoing conflict severely limits digital infrastructure and access. Among lowest globally for tech adoption. Estimated from conflict-affected country patterns.

data.source: Lloyd's Register Foundation World Risk Poll 2021
data.notes: World Risk Poll: 62% believe AI will mostly harm people (highest concern in East Africa). Only ~25% believe AI will mostly help. Score reflects high concern/low acceptance.
Central/Western Africa region in World Risk Poll showed majority saying AI will mostly harm. Very low digital infrastructure. Among lowest globally for tech readiness.
No direct AI survey data. Oil-wealthy but limited digital infrastructure. Estimated from Sub-Saharan African regional patterns.
No direct AI survey. North Africa region in World Risk Poll showed higher harm concerns. National AI strategy emerging. Estimated from North African patterns and Morocco comparison.
Among top Sub-Saharan/North African countries in Oxford Insights. Strong tech sector relative to region. Arab Barometer included Tunisia. Estimated from indices and North African patterns.
Among top countries in West Africa for AI readiness (Oxford Insights). Francophone West Africa with growing tech ecosystem. Estimated from readiness indices.
No direct AI survey data. Growing economy and digital sector in Francophone West Africa. Estimated from regional patterns.
Oxford Insights: Rwanda leads Sub-Saharan Africa in government AI support (score 71.44). Strong digital governance and vision. Higher acceptance estimated due to government promotion of tech.

data.source: Lloyd's Register Foundation World Risk Poll 2021
data.notes: World Risk Poll: 57% believe AI will mostly harm people. Relatively low acceptance of AI. Growing tech hub in Kampala but limited national infrastructure.
World Risk Poll regional data: Central/Western Africa majority said AI will mostly harm. Afrobarometer 2025 survey included Cameroon. Estimated from regional patterns.
Conflict-affected country with very limited digital infrastructure. Low-income country. Estimated from regional patterns and development indicators.
Low-income country with limited internet penetration. No direct AI survey data. Estimated from East African regional patterns.
Low-income country with growing mobile connectivity. No direct AI survey. Estimated from East African regional patterns.
Educated population but economic challenges limit tech adoption. No direct AI survey. Estimated from Southern African patterns and South Africa comparison.
Growing digital economy. No direct AI survey data. Estimated from regional patterns.
Ongoing conflict severely limits digital infrastructure. Very low internet penetration. Estimated from conflict-affected country patterns.
Strong IT sector and education system. Asian Barometer has included Sri Lanka. Oxford Insights shows growing AI readiness. Estimated from South Asian patterns and India comparison.
Growing IT sector but limited infrastructure. Asian Barometer included Nepal. Estimated from South Asian patterns.
ILIA 2024 evaluated Ecuador among 19 Latin American countries. Estimated from Latin American regional patterns and Peru/Colombia comparisons.
IMD rank 67 (22.00) - lowest in their ranking. Economic crisis limits tech adoption. Educated population. Estimated from Latin American patterns adjusted for economic conditions.
ILIA 2024 included Paraguay. Growing digital economy. Estimated from Latin American regional patterns.
ILIA 2024 score: 64.98 (3rd in Latin America). Perfect Vision score (100) in Oxford Insights. Strong digital infrastructure for the region. High human capital score (62.11).
Limited internet access and economic constraints. Strong education system. No direct AI survey data. Estimated from Caribbean patterns and infrastructure limitations.
ILIA 2024: noted as having good governance for AI. Growing digital economy. Estimated from Latin American patterns and ILIA assessment.
Limited digital infrastructure. No direct AI survey. ILIA 2024 covered Guatemala. Estimated from Central American patterns.
Limited digital infrastructure. No direct AI survey. Estimated from Central American patterns.
ILIA 2024 included Bolivia. Moderate digital development. Estimated from Andean regional patterns.
Perfect Vision score (100) in Oxford Insights. ILIA 2024: infrastructure score 55.86, computational capacity 51.11. Strong tech sector. Estimated from indices and regional data.
ILIA 2024: leader in open source production in Latin America. Growing digital economy as regional financial hub. Estimated from ILIA assessment and regional patterns.
IMD rank 46 (57.00). Eurobarometer 554: 79% fear AI will replace more jobs than create (2nd highest in EU after Greece). High concern drives lower acceptance score despite decent tech infrastructure.
IMD rank 61 (43.00). EU member. Moderate AI acceptance typical of Central European EU countries. Estimated from Eurobarometer EU average (60% positive) and regional patterns.
IMD rank 47 (56.00). EU member since 2013. Moderate AI attitudes similar to other Central-South European EU countries. Estimated from Eurobarometer patterns.
EU candidate country. Growing tech sector, especially in Belgrade. Not covered by Eurobarometer. Estimated from Western Balkans patterns and readiness indices.

IMD rank 50 (54.00). Eurostat 2025: GenAI for work 8.43%, private use 20.15%, business AI adoption 8.55%. Relatively low AI usage despite EU membership. Acceptance estimated from Eurobarometer and usage data.
IMD rank 35 (67.50). ITU score 95.1. Eurobarometer 554: 32% distrust AI vs 31% trust (trust deficit). High tech infrastructure but cautious AI attitudes.
IMD rank 25 (74.50). ITU score 95.3. Strong digital infrastructure. EU member with growing tech sector. Estimated from Baltic/EU patterns.
IMD rank 26 (74.00). Eurostat 2025: GenAI private use 35.71%, business AI adoption 33.61%. High-income EU country. Moderate AI acceptance typical of Western Europe.
IMD rank 19 (79.00). ITU score 95.9. Nordic country with very high digital infrastructure. Estimated from Nordic/Scandinavian patterns (lower AI excitement typical of Nordics).

ITU score 95.0. Eurobarometer 554: 65% optimistic about AI solving global challenges (3rd highest in EU). Eurostat 2025: GenAI for education 20.22%, work 29.64%, private 37.20%. National AI strategy. Strong fintech sector.

IMD rank 60 (44.00). Eurobarometer 554: 77% concerned about AI job replacement (3rd highest in EU). Eurostat 2025: highest GenAI private use in EU (43.13%) but low business adoption (9.27%). Mixed pattern of personal enthusiasm but institutional caution.
EU candidate country. Not covered by Eurobarometer. Growing IT outsourcing sector. Estimated from Western Balkans patterns.
EU candidate country. Growing IT sector. Not covered by Eurobarometer. Estimated from Western Balkans patterns.
EU candidate country. Small economy with growing digital sector. Estimated from Western Balkans patterns.
EU candidate country. Growing tech sector and outsourcing industry. Estimated from Western Balkans patterns.
Very limited internet penetration and digital infrastructure. Among lowest globally for tech readiness. Estimated from Pacific Island patterns.
Better digital infrastructure than most Pacific Islands. Growing digital economy. Estimated from Pacific regional patterns.
IMD rank 64 (38.00). Asian Barometer has included Mongolia. Growing tech sector. Estimated from East Asian development patterns.
IMD rank 62 (42.00). Among most developed economies in Sub-Saharan Africa. Strong governance. Estimated from Southern African patterns.
IMD rank 7 (88.11). ITU score 97.6. Microsoft Work Trend Index 2024 included Hong Kong. Strong financial tech hub. Estimated from East Asian patterns and index data.
Growing tech hub in Tbilisi. Moderate digital infrastructure. Estimated from Caucasus/Eastern European patterns.
Oxford Insights 2025: jumped 41 places in global AI readiness index. Oil-wealthy with growing digital ambitions. Estimated from Caucasus patterns.
Growing IT sector and tech startup scene. Strong engineering education. Estimated from Caucasus/Eastern European patterns.
